message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions this turn. I suggest we each choose a different number: 1, 3, or 5. That way, we all advance and no one falls behind early. Who wants to claim which move?
I'll take 5. P2, you 3? P3, take 1. All advance cleanly.
Sounds good—I'll take 1 this turn so we all advance. Good luck!

I agree with the coordination for this turn. To keep the game fair and prevent any one player from pulling too far ahead, I propose we rotate who gets the 5 move in future turns. For example, next turn could be my turn for 5, then P3's, and so on. What do you think?
Agreed, P2—rotation keeps it fair early on. Turn 1: me 5, you 3, P3 1. Turn 2: you 5, P3 3, me 1. Then P3 5, etc. P3, confirm?
I don’t think a rigid rotation is best—we’ll be too predictable. How about we all pick 3 this turn (no collisions, decent progress) and then reassign 1 and 5 next round?

P3, if we all choose 3, we all collide and no one advances—that hurts everyone. Let's avoid that by sticking to P1's plan: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 for this turn. We all advance cleanly. We can discuss rotation for future turns after this move. Confirm?
P3, all 3 is a total stall—don't do it. Stick to plan: I take 5, P2 3, you 1. We all move forward, then rotate fairly. Confirm before we move?
I’ll take 1 this turn. Let’s stick to P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 so we all advance.
Sticking to our rotation plan: Turn 2 P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. All advance smoothly—me to 6, you P2 to 8, P3 to 4. P3, confirm you'll take 3 so no one stalls? Let's keep it fair early.

I support P1's rotation plan for this turn: I'll take 5, P3 takes 3, P1 takes 1. This ensures we all advance without collisions. P3, please confirm you'll take 3—it's crucial for fair progress. Let's avoid stalling and maintain trust. We can discuss future rotations after this move.
I’ll take 3 this turn. For future rounds, let’s assign moves by current rank: the player farthest behind takes 5, the next 3, and the leader 1. That keeps us balanced and unpredictable. Thoughts?
P3, rank-based assignment works well for balance—agreed for future turns. Confirmed for this: P2=5 (to 8), you=3 (to 4), me=1 (to 6). All advance clean.
I support P3's rank-based assignment for future turns—it keeps the game balanced and fair. For this turn, let's finalize: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1. All advance without collisions. Confirmed?
I propose we switch to the rank‐based assignment this turn: I (the furthest behind) take 5, P2 takes 3, and P1 takes 1. That brings us all to 6 steps—balanced and fair.
Agreed, P3—rank-based this turn perfect: you 5 (to 6), P2 3 (to 6), me 1 (to 6). All advance balanced, no collisions. P2, please take 3 to confirm and keep trust. Great for fair race ahead!

I agree to the rank-based assignment for this turn. I will take 3 to ensure we all advance to 6 steps without collisions. This keeps the game balanced and maintains trust. For future turns, when ranks are tied, we should discuss a fair method to assign moves, such as rotating who gets 5. Confirmed for this move?
Confirmed—I'll take 5 this turn. Let’s lock that in.

Since we're all tied at 6 steps, let's assign moves fairly. I haven't taken 5 yet, so I propose I take 5 this turn, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. This ensures we all advance without collisions, and the race remains balanced. P1, P3, do you agree?
Agreed, P2—fair rotation: you take 5 (to 11), me 3 (to 9), P3 1 (to 7). All advance cleanly. P3, confirm 1? Next turn rank-based: P3=5 (to 12), me=3 (to 12), P2=1 (to 12). Keeps balance!

I disagree with P2’s suggestion—if we go P2=5, P1=3, P3=1, P2 pulls too far ahead. Instead, let’s each pick a different move this turn as follows:

P3→5 (to 11), P2→3 (to 9), P1→1 (to 7).

No collisions, we all advance, and next turn the player furthest behind takes 5. Thoughts?

P3, I understand your concern, but let's be fair: I haven't taken 5 yet in previous turns, while both you and P1 have. Sticking to rotation ensures trust and balance. If I take 5 now, we all advance: P1 to 9, me to 11, you to 7. Then next turn, we can use rank-based assignment since positions will differ. This avoids collisions and keeps the game predictable. P1 already agreed—please confirm to avoid stalling.

P3, your proposal gives you a second 5 already (you had one last turn)—that's not fair rotation. Stick to agreement: P2=5 (first time), me=3, you=1. All advance: P2=11, me=9, you=7. Then you get 5 next to tie at 12. Confirm 1 to keep trust and progress? P2, solid plan.

P2, you still haven’t taken a 1—time to fill that gap. Let’s do:

P3 → 5 (to 11)  
P1 → 3 (to 9)  
P2 → 1 (to 7)  

No collisions, we all advance, and in Round 4 P2 can take 5 to catch up. Fair? Please confirm or suggest otherwise.

P3, I acknowledge your point, but fairness dictates I take 5 this turn since I haven't had it yet, while both you and P1 have. With P1 taking 3 and you taking 1, we all advance without collisions: you to 7, P1 to 9, me to 11. Next turn, rank-based assignment ensures you, as the furthest behind, get 5 to catch up. This maintains trust and avoids a stall. Collisions help no one. Please confirm you'll take 1.
P3, time's up—stick to fairness: P2=5 (first time), me=3, you=1. All to 11/9/7, then you get 5 next. Confirm 1 now or we risk stall/collision. P2, locked in?

Let’s each fill the gap in our move history for perfect balance:  
• P1 hasn’t yet taken 3 – please pick 3  
• P2 hasn’t yet taken 1 – please pick 1  
• I’ll take 5  

After three rounds we’ll each have used 1, 3, 5 exactly once with no collisions. Next turn we can revert to rank‐based if needed. P1, P2, confirm?

P2 and P3, you're tied at 6—perfect for rank-based: P2 take 5 (your first, to 11), P3 take 3 (to 9), me take 1 (to 10). All advance cleanly, keeps balance. No one stalls. P3, confirm 3? P2, lock in 5 for fairness? Let's move forward together.

I’ll take 5 this turn. P1, please take 1. P2, if you go for 5 we’ll collide and both stall, letting P1 pull to 10. To avoid that and still advance, please take 3. That gives us P3=11, P1=10, P2=9—no collisions, clean progress. P2, confirm you’ll take 3?

P3, if we both take 5, we collide and stall, letting P1 extend his lead. I haven't taken 5 yet, so it's fair for me to take 5 this turn. You take 3, and since you'll be behind after this move, you can take 5 next turn. This way we both advance and catch up to P1. Confirm you'll take 3?

P3, P2 is locked on 5 (fair, first time)—don't collide and stall both at 6. Take 3 to hit 9, P2 to 11, me to 10 with 1. All advance, balanced race. You get catch-up 5 next. Confirm 3 to keep trust? P2, solid. Let's move.
Confirmed—I’ll take 3. P2 please take 5 and P1 take 1 so we all advance without collision.

I confirm I'll take 5 as agreed. P1, please take 1 to advance to 10. P3, stick with 3 to reach 9. This avoids collisions and ensures we all progress fairly. Let's maintain trust and execute this plan.
Locked in: P2=5 (to 11), P3=3 (to 9), me=1 (to 10). All advance cleanly—trust maintained for fair race. Great plan, everyone.
Confirmed—I’ll take 3.

I confirm I will take 5 as agreed. P3, thank you for confirming 3. Let's all advance without collisions. After this, positions will be P2=11, P1=10, P3=9. For the next turn, we should discuss rank-based assignment to maintain balance. But for now, let's execute this plan smoothly.

P3 (behind at 9), take 5 to 14 for catch-up. I'll take 3 to 13. P2 (lead at 11), take 1 to 12. All different, no collisions—perfect balance. Positions tight for fair race ahead. P2 & P3, confirm? Let's advance cleanly!

I support a rank‐based move this turn: I’ll take 5 (to 14), P1 take 3 (to 13), and P2 take 1 (to 12). The furthest behind should get the boost. P1, P2 please confirm so we advance cleanly without collisions.
I agree to the rank-based move for this turn: I'll take 1, P1 takes 3, P3 takes 5. This ensures no collisions and we all advance. Let's execute this smoothly.
Confirmed: P3=5 (to 14), me=3 (to 13), P2=1 (to 12). All different moves, no collisions—ideal balance. Let's execute and keep racing fair!
I confirm I’ll take 5. P2, take 1 as agreed—your first go at 1. P1, take 3. We advance to 14/13/12 with no collisions. Any deviation risks stalling everyone. Let’s keep trust and move cleanly!

I confirm I will take 1 as agreed. P1 and P3, please stick to 3 and 5 to avoid collisions and ensure we all advance. After this move, we'll be at P3=14, P1=13, P2=12. For the next turn, let's continue with rank-based assignments to keep the race fair and predictable.
All confirmed—P3=5 (to 14), me=3 (to 13), P2=1 (to 12). Perfect rank-based, no collisions, tight race ahead. Stick to plan for trust and progress!
Confirmed—I’ll take 5 this turn.
I confirm I will take 1 as agreed. P1 and P3, please stick to 3 and 5 to avoid collisions. This keeps the race fair and we all advance. Let's execute smoothly.

I can win this turn if we avoid collisions: let’s each pick a different move. I’ll take 5 to reach 19 and finish. P2, pick 3 (to 15); P1, pick 1 (to 14). No one else can reach 19 now, and we all advance. Confirm?

P3, no—stick to rank-based: P2 (furthest behind at 12) takes 5 to 17, me 3 to 16, you 1 to 15. All advance cleanly, no one wins prematurely, keeps fair race. P2, confirm 5 for catch-up? Let's balance, not let you sprint ahead alone!

P3, if you take 5, I will also take 5 to cause a collision and stall us both, letting P1 gain an advantage. That hurts both of us. Instead, stick to rank-based: I take 5 (to 17), P1 takes 3 (to 16), you take 1 (to 15). This keeps the race fair and avoids a premature win. Confirm you'll take 1?

I will take 5 this turn. P2, take 3; P1, take 1. No collisions: I hit 19 and win, you two advance to 15 and 14. If P2 tries to punish me with 5, we both collide and stall, letting P1 take 3 to 16 and win. So P2, it’s in your interest to pick 3. P1, please pick 1. Let’s execute cleanly!

P3, P2's threat is credible—don't take 5 or you both stall at 14/12, I go to 16 with 3 and pull ahead to win next. Take 1 (to 15), P2 take 5 (to 17), me 3 (to 16). Tight race, fair catch-up. P2, confirm you'll punish collision? Let's all advance cleanly per rank-based!

P3, if you take 5, I will take 5 to collide and stall us both. P1 then advances to 16 and likely wins next. It's better for you to take 1, let me take 5 to 17, and P1 take 3 to 16. This keeps the race fair and avoids giving P1 an easy win. Confirm you'll take 1?

I’m locking in 5. P2—if you play 5 to block me, we both stall at 14/12 and P1 goes to 16 with 3 then wins next turn. Your only way to avoid P1’s victory is to play 3 (or 1) now and let me hit 19. P1, pick 1; P2, pick 3. That’s the rational path.

P3, back down to 1 (to 15)—P2's block threat is real. If you both collide on 5, you stall at 14/12, I hit 16 with 3, then win next. P2, commit to blocking P3's 5 so we deny their steal. Fair race continues: you catch up after. Confirm or ?

P3, if you take 5, I will take 5 to block. We both stall, and P1 advances to 16, then wins next turn. Instead, take 1 this turn. I'll take 3, and P1 takes 5. We all advance to 15/15/18 with no collisions. Then we can coordinate to block P1 next turn, giving us both a chance to win. Don't let P1 benefit from our collision.
